It was intended to be the battle that decided the outcome of the war; in reality it turned out to be somewhat of a 'bloody' draw as each side fielded 15,000 inexperienced troops. Although he had taken control of the road to London, King Charles failed to seize the initiative and withdrew his army to Oxford, his capital for the rest of the war. The inconclusive result of the battle prevented either side gaining a quick victory and the war would drag on for four more years.
